ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: New Paper Combining Evolution and Deep Learning
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, Thanks for the summary of your DDFA reviews. Itâ€™s very interesting to see the responses. I had a similar spectrum of responses to our Fooling paper

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: New Paper Combining Evolution and Deep Learning
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=4W7A0_y6y2iMEDzwwmYNqyCRYK6YkIWQrjuO9fZNgGAzGslXaYs5

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Hi Ken,

Thanks for the summary of your DDFA reviews. It=E2=80=99s very int=
eresting to see the responses. I had a similar spectrum of responses to our=
 Fooling paper at NIPS, because it also includes an evolutionary component.=
 I find that there is a lot of animosity towards EAs, but also a fair bit o=
f curiosity since people want to know more about them, especially the claim=
 that evolution is =E2=80=9Ccreative=E2=80=9D. 

As for the Creative Thinki=
ng Approach plus Deep Learning, it=E2=80=99s still early days, so we don=E2=
=80=99t have a lot to share=E2=80=A6but I do think there=E2=80=99s somethin=
g exciting about the idea so we=E2=80=99ll be pursuing it. I=E2=80=99m glad=
 you like it too!

Happy new year everyone! 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

As=
sistant Professor, Computer Science
Director, Evolving Artificial Intellige=
nce Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
j=
effclune.com

> On Dec 31, 2014, at 3:16 AM, kstanley@... [neat] =
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> Hi Jeff, interesting question on how the=
 more traditional AI community reacts to the idea of non-objective search. =
 My impression from AAAI reviewers is that it's a very unfamiliar concept t=
o them, so their reactions tend to be unpredictable and polarized.  For exa=
mple, one reviewer was so struck by the proposition of non-objective search=
 that the review was mostly a critique of novelty search, even though the p=
aper is about DDFA and novelty search is just background.  Others took it m=
ore in stride, but were more concerned with how diversity alone could possi=
bly lead to a good set of features.  Another view stridently expressed was =
that you should not need evolution to do non-objective search.  It was inte=
resting that the reviewer felt so passionately about that given that the DD=
FA would not really be impacted if that were so (since presumably you could=
 then just plug in the non-evolutionary version of non-objective search ins=
tead), but it just shows that there was some irritation that we even perhap=
s inadvertently implied that there is something you need evolution to do.  =
On the other hand, the potential for non-objective algorithms outside evolu=
tion is of course interesting to consider as well, so it's a constructive t=
hought even if a bit of a knee-jerk response.
> 
> However, one reviewer wa=
s highly intrigued by the idea, and my guess is that that reviewer was like=
ly someone influential from deep learning, because their review seemed to t=
ip the balance.  If you consider that the paper was a bit lighter on experi=
mentation than most deep learning papers tend to be today (i.e. only applyi=
ng DDFA to MNIST), and that  the combination of such a preliminary study wi=
th an evolutionary method would normally be very difficult to get into AAAI=
, I think it shows that the non-objective stuff can be a wildcard that actu=
ally can excite some people in the mainstream.  Of course, that was part of=
 our hope in sending DDFA to AAAI, that by hitching non-objective search to=
 deep learning it could serve as one possible vehicle for getting these kin=
ds of ideas into other communities.  I'm sure other non-objective approache=
s will start seeping in as well.  In fact, as you recall it seemed like Yos=
hua Bengio was kind of groping in that direction in his GECCO keynote.
> 
>=
 By the way, interesting idea on the "Creative Thinking Approach for DNNs."=
  I'm not sure how that would interact with gradient descent/backprop style=
 learning though?  Or maybe I shouldn't be asking on a public forum if it's=
 a work in progress!  Still a cool idea in any case.
> 
> Best,
> 
> ken
> =

> 


--Apple-Mail=_1800C198-8BF4-4F65-8EFE-593391484A8E

Content-Type: text/html;

    <di=
v id=3D"ygrp-text" class=3D""><p class=3D"">Hi Jeff, interesting question o=
n how the more traditional AI community reacts to the idea of non-objective=
 search.  My impression from AAAI reviewers is that it's a very unfami=
liar concept to them, so their reactions tend to be unpredictable and polar=
ized.  For example, one reviewer was so struck by the proposition of n=
on-objective search that the review was mostly a critique of novelty search=
, even though the paper is about DDFA and novelty search is just background=
.  Others took it more in stride, but were more concerned with how div=
ersity alone could possibly lead to a good set of features.  Another v=
iew stridently expressed was that you should not need evolution to do non-o=
bjective search.  It was interesting that the reviewer felt so passion=
ately about that given that the DDFA would not really be impacted if that w=
ere so (since presumably you could then just plug in the non-evolutionary v=
ersion of non-objective search instead), but it just shows that there was s=
ome irritation that we even perhaps inadvertently implied that there is som=
ething you need evolution to do.  On the other hand, the potential for=
 non-objective algorithms outside evolution is of course interesting to con=
sider as well, so it's a constructive thought even if a bit of a knee-jerk =
response.<br class=3D""><br class=3D"">However, one reviewer was highly int=
rigued by the idea, and my guess is that that reviewer was likely someone i=
nfluential from deep learning, because their review seemed to tip the balan=
ce.  If you consider that the paper was a bit lighter on experimentati=
on than most deep learning papers tend to be today (i.e. only applying DDFA=
 to MNIST), and that  the combination of such a preliminary study with=
 an evolutionary method would normally be very difficult to get into AAAI, =
I think it shows that the non-objective stuff can be a wildcard that actual=
ly can excite some people in the mainstream.  Of course, that was part=
 of our hope in sending DDFA to AAAI, that by hitching non-objective search=
 to deep learning it could serve as one possible vehicle for getting these =
kinds of ideas into other communities.  I'm sure other non-objective a=
pproaches will start seeping in as well.  In fact, as you recall it se=
emed like Yoshua Bengio was kind of groping in that direction in his GECCO =
keynote.<br class=3D""><br class=3D"">By the way, interesting idea on the "=
<span class=3D"ygrps-yiv-614408715s1">Creative Thinking Approach for DNNs."=
  I'm not sure how that would interact with gradient descent/backprop =
style learning though?  Or maybe I shouldn't be asking on a public for=
um if it's a work in progress!  Still a cool idea in any case.</span><=
br class=3D""><br class=3D"">Best,<br class=3D""><br class=3D"">ken</p>

  =
  </div>
